title: Lament by the Rivers of Babylon
shortSummary: Psalm 137 expresses the deep sorrow and longing of the Jewish exiles in Babylon as they remember their beloved Jerusalem. It captures the pain of captivity, the struggle to worship God in a foreign land, and a call for divine justice against their oppressors. This psalm vividly portrays the tension between mourning, faithfulness, and righteous judgment.
timeline: c. 586 BC - Babylonian Exile following the destruction of Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: The Exiles
keyCharacters.description: The Jewish captives in Babylon mourning the loss of Jerusalem and their homeland.

keyCharacters.name: The Babylonians
keyCharacters.description: The captors who demand the exiles to sing songs of Zion, representing the oppressors in this psalm.

keyCharacters.name: The Edomites
keyCharacters.description: A neighboring people who rejoiced over Jerusalem’s destruction and are called to remembrance for their hostility.

keyCharacters.name: Jerusalem (Zion)
keyCharacters.description: The holy city and spiritual center of Israel, deeply missed and longed for by the exiles.

definitions.definition: Trees with drooping branches, often found near water; here symbolizing sorrow as the exiles hung their harps on them.
A stringed musical instrument used in worship and celebration, representing the joyful songs of Zion now silenced in exile.
An archaic term meaning to utterly destroy or demolish, used here to describe the destruction of Jerusalem.
A Hebrew idiom meaning to lose skill or ability, expressing the psalmist’s commitment to never forget Jerusalem.

outline.heading: The Exiles’ Lament and Mourning
outline.description: The psalm opens with the exiles sitting by the rivers of Babylon, weeping as they remember Zion and hanging their harps on willow trees, symbolizing their grief and inability to sing joyfully in captivity.

outline.heading: Oppressors Demand Songs of Zion
outline.description: The captors mockingly demand songs of joy from the exiles, but the psalmist questions how they can sing the LORD’s song in a foreign land, highlighting the spiritual and emotional struggle of worship in exile.

outline.heading: A Solemn Oath to Remember Jerusalem
outline.description: The psalmist makes a solemn vow never to forget Jerusalem, emphasizing the city’s supreme importance above all personal joy and skill.

outline.heading: Call for Divine Justice Against Enemies
outline.description: The psalm ends with a plea for God to remember the hostility of Edom and Babylon, pronouncing a harsh judgment on Babylon for its cruelty, reflecting the desire for righteous retribution.

application: Remember and cherish your spiritual heritage, even in times of hardship and exile.
Maintain faithfulness to God’s worship and truth, refusing to conform to ungodly demands or pressures.
Pray earnestly for justice and trust God to vindicate His people in His perfect timing.
Express your grief honestly before God, knowing He understands the pain of loss and exile.

keyVerses.text: How shall we sing the LORD'S song in a strange land?
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the heartache of worshiping God in a foreign land and the spiritual dislocation experienced by the exiles.

keyVerses.text: If I forget thee, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget her cunning.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn vow expressing the psalmist’s unwavering commitment to remember and honor Jerusalem above all else.

keyVerses.text: Remember, O LORD, the children of Edom in the day of Jerusalem; who said, Rase it, rase it, even to the foundation thereof.
keyVerses.significance: A call for God’s justice against those who rejoiced over Jerusalem’s destruction, emphasizing God’s role as defender of His people.
